Title: How the Web Storage API Works

Title: Subqueries in MySQL - Simple Talk
Description: A subquery is a type of query that is embeddedâ€”or nestedâ€”into a data manipulation language (DML) statement. The data returned by the subquery is passed into the DML statement and incorporated into its overall logic. The subquery itself is typically a SELECT statement, although you can also use a TABLE statement or VALUES statement. Even so, the SELECT statement continues to be the most common choice for subqueries, and thatâ€™s the one I focus on in this article.

Title: Our journey to F#: C#-F# Interop â€“ planetgeek.ch
Description: When we started with TimeRocket in 2015, we used C# as the programming language for our backend. In 2020, we started using F# for our new code. We see little value in rewriting existing C# code to F# and do so only when major changes are due in existing C# code. As a result, we have quite a bit of C#-F# interop in our system. Both from C# to F# and from F# to C#. This post overviews what we learned about C#-F# interop.

Title: Deep linking with Azure Static Web Apps and Easy Auth | I CAN MAKE THIS WORK
Description: Azure Static Web Apps doesn't support deep linking with authentication. This is a problem for many applications. This post describes how to work around this limitation.

Title: Refactoring Bloated Controllers with [FromService] - ElegantCode
Description: Instead of use the Service Locator pattern to tidy up your ASP.NET MVC controllers, consider using the [FromService] attribute to provide even greater cleanliness and separation of concerns to your classes.

Title: Polly with .NET 6, Part 7 - Policy Wraps with Minimal APIs, and HttpClientFactory | no dogma blog
Description: In the previous post I showed how to pass a Polly Policy Wrap into an Minimal API endpoint with dependency injection. In this post I'll show to use the Policy Wrap with the Http Client Factory, passing that into the endpoint.

Title: Domain-Driven Microservices with F#
Description: It is well-known, or at least well-documented, that F# is an excellent language for doing type-driven development using domain driven design, although it may be less well known that F# is an excellent language for microservices.
